If Stardew Valley had been released when I was playing Harvest Moon 64 on my old CRT, I probably would have melted out of happiness. The way it almost magically reproduces the same feeling of walking into a tiny town where everyone has their weird things, secrets, and work hours that you wouldn't really believe... but still it feels like home is something unique to it. 

In my childhood, while playing Harvest Moon 64, I would get so excited with the moment of my first row of turnips that I could swear I was doing a sacred ritual. The music was calm, the villagers had just enough personality to intrigue my little brain, and the whole world was incredibly warm. Stardew Valley actually brings back that very emotional memory and it says, "Hey, do you remember that? Let's do it again but bigger, deeper, and somehow more personal." 

This game is more than just a farm simulator, the emotional aspect is its main feature. Every day is a small adventure: you could be mining, fishing, or running madly across town because you forgot it was someone's birthday and you want to give them a flower like a frenzied postman. The villagers are very real characters, in fact, they remind me of the old days when every heart event was like finding a new page of someone's diary. 

What about the nostalgia? It is there... very strong. Such moments like standing on your farm porch when it is raining or watching the fireflies lighting up the night are exactly the same as those long childhood nights spent trying to marry Karen or figure out what the heck Kappa really was. 

But besides being the spiritual successor of Harvest Moon 64, Stardew Valley is its mature, emotionally savvy, and endlessly attractive evolution. The game is not stuck in the past but it is still there to pay homage to that era. It is that warm feeling of belonging which you get to experience once again through this game... yet you can also have everything on sprinklers, become friends with a wizard, fight cave monsters, or turn your farm into a vineyard because you are worthy of nice things. 

To put it shortly if you were a fan of Harvest Moon 64 during your childhood, then Stardew Valley isn't just a familiar notion, it is like returning home after a long time and seeing that the porch light is still on.

The game is cute in the beginning but quickly becomes a repetitive slog. 

The game does not explain its mechanics at all, it depends completely on fan made content to make it playable for a new player. 

Fishing is the best example of course, fans of this game lol about how hard fishing is. But it's not only hard mechanically, in the beginning I couldn't understand what I was supposed to do at all. So if you stop fishing completely, Willy comes to you and asks you why you aren't fishing. If you say it's too hard, he gives you training rod, says he will give you a lesson. That just gives you one fishing level for free but still doesn't explain what you're supposed to do. It's like the dev clearly sees that fishing is just a mess in this game but decided to just shrug it off.
And you need to fish to progress the game...
This makes the game unbalanced because you progress all the other skills too fast compared to fishing, 

Then there's making friends with characters... It's mostly giving them gifts, doing their quests and hoping for a cut scene...
And finding these people in time to give them a gift without the wiki is near impossible - and you need to chase them around to give them gifts and finish their quests.
Ah, the mini quests, they start on the day you pick them up and you need to chase the character to close them on the next day, So you need to pick them up early enough to finish them on the same day you pick them up and then chase down the character who requested it the next day. 
There's so much timed stuff to keep track of, it gets stressful very quickly.

If someone is starting with this game, my one tip is ignore chasing the quests early on. It will only frustrate you.

Stardew Valley has been my favorite farming game for a good five years now. Having played through a new save on Steam and almost reaching perfection again at the time of writing this review, it's just as calming, fun, and open-ended as I remembered. As a gamer with the attention span and general gameplay interests of a caveman, it's pretty crazy that something that appears so mundane and simple at a surface level is one of the most addicting things I've ever played.

This game has been around long enough that the best it has to offer has already been parroted by tons of people, so I'll try to keep the things I love most pretty brief. Progression is perfect and moves at a pace that's simultaneously slow enough that the game always always feels relaxing, yet fast enough that all of the seasonal content the game has to offer returns semi-frequently and it's not quite as agonizing if you accidentally forget to/run out of time to do something during a certain season. NPC townsfolk are designed great, having unique schedules and interests and pretty engaging storylines for the most part. There's a ton of ways you can make money, and with the right setup any of them can be extremely profitable, which makes the gameplay fundamentally super open-ended. That paired with the sheer diversity of things you can do in a single year cycle and the (SPOILER FOR ENDGAME AREA) [spoiler]giant distant island with a colossal amount of unique content you can access late in the game[/spoiler] gives this game a pretty insane longevity that provides hundreds of hours of engagement, and ensures that there's a dozen other projects you can focus on if you can't finish something season-specific.

It's been said by many already, but I can concur that this game has something for everyone. Tons of avenues of farming and ranching for whatever playstyle you have the most fun with, well-designed and fun combat that can be challenging but rarely feels like you're unfairly screwed over, open-ended building and different farm layouts that can allow for breathtakingly beautiful farms, tons of varied NPCs of different age groups you can choose to make friends with or pursue romantically (or not, you can be a sigma lone wolf too, with zero consequences), cross-platform co-op if you'd like to play with a friend or partner, Steam Deck compatibility (which I can't comment further on as I don't have one), and some fun lore that you by no means need to care about at all to enjoy the game but also adds some very welcome charm and mystique to the world if it does interest you, all for the frankly stupid price of only $15 USD. There are very few games that provide this level of content and quality with an indie pricetag, and it's fantastic that we have a charming and relaxing life sim in that boat, as a majority of them tend to lean towards being fast, fun, and high-octane action/adventure/platformer titles. 

There's a million other things to gush about, but I'll leave it at that so as to not spoil anything for anyone. It's worth mentioning I don't play with mods apart from a few small quality-of-life things, but a single browse through Nexus will make it obvious there's a pretty wild modding community working diligently to enhance the game even further. This game is an unbelievably good value for $15, even going on sale occasionally, and comes packaged with so much varied content it's highly unlikely you wouldn't enjoy the game (though I think it also does a good job playing enough of its cards in the first two hours that you'll know very well if this game simply isn't for you and you want to refund it). I can't do anything but strongly recommend giving Stardew a try. The amount of positive reception it continues to get almost a decade after release and its stagnant Overwhelmingly Positive rating on this platform says enough; this game is WELL worth your money. Thank you for helping me through some of the hardest times of my life with your funny little farming game, Mr. Ape.

"Just one more day" becomes your mantra. You'll find yourself saying, "Okay, just gonna water my crops, pet my chickens, maybe go fishing... wait, it's 2 AM in-game and I'm risking passing out to catch one more carp."

Before you know it, you're not just a farmer. You're a artisanal mayonnaise tycoon, a master angler, a legendary monster slayer in the mines, and the town's #1 matchmaker. The skill progression is so satisfying it should be illegal.

Content for Decades

Ah, Stardew Valley. An absolute classic. You can probably infer from my hours played that I really like this game. Stardew has it all: cozy farming simulator, incredibly rich world building and npcs who will have you obsessed if you pay attention to what they say, lots of room for personal design and creativity, a plethora of choices to make, and genuinely challenging gameplay in many areas. 

I will caution new players to not overdo their play time. Although stardew is a wonderful game, it is a little too good at getting you hooked. Try to limit your play sessions to 2-3 hours max, if not less. Otherwise, it is VERY easy to burn out early. And that sucks for everyone, because you will definitely not make it long enough to experience all the game has to offer if you don't pace yourself. 

My other criticism is mostly around the late game experience. Opportunities like Ginger Island and the Skull Cave mean you do have things to do around year 3/4, but it's quite difficult to really dive into those, because at that point in the game you have a very active farm that needs daily tending to. So you're constantly jumping back and forth and not doing either the best you could. 

I finished the skull cave but mostly ignored Ginger Island at this point in the game, and instead opted for mods, which has been a great decision for me. There is a very thriving modding community on this game and you should totally check it out even as a first time player. There are simple mods out there that won't interfere with your "genuine" experience, but will just get rid of some minor annoyances that don't do the game any good. 

If I could add anything to this game it would be making spouses and children more helpful. I am begging concerned ape to let us assign chores to our spouse and kids, once they're grown. I would also love if the children were a little bit more anything. They barely qualify as npcs right now in my book. 

I still recommend this game, which is very close to my heart!!

Some games will give you the power fantasy of carving through demons, some will have you leading armies and out-smarting your enemies. This game gives you the ultimate power fantasy for a man in 2025: living off the land with a beautiful wife and kids. And the only demons you're fighting off are A) the evil Amazon stand-in and B) the stupid effing flying enemies that drag the game to a halt as you stand there knocking them away and waiting for them to bounce back like the slowest, most boring game of paddle ball in the universe. Combat sucks.

There'll inevitably be that time where you realize that you're 90% done with the game, even if that 10% will take a hefty while to achieve, and that'll drag down your mood. But it'll take you _quite_ a while to get there, and it's all worth it for that sense of accomplishment. And if the problem is, "Aw, I was hoping there'd be just a *little* bit more," then I'd say, after forty-something hours, that's a freakin' accomplishment.

If I had only _one_ piece of feedback...we could *maybe* have enemies die in less than twenty hits. Maybe. Definitely. Absolutely. Enemies shouldn't take nearly twenty hits to kill with the highest-level sword in the game. We ain't here for the paddle ball, Eric - we're here for the *literally everything else*. The likable npcs, the cute gals, the mysteries, and the soil. And fishing, sometimes. When I'm in the mood. I'm not often in the mood. But we're getting off track.

Some people may have told you that Stardew Valley is a chill game about farming and making friends. Someone might have told you that this is an easy going, relaxing game that can be enjoyed by anyone, even those who don't normally play video games. Those people were wrong. Stardew Valley is not really a game at all; it is a mirror, reflecting within it the darkness of the human condition, and my own inability to escape it. 

At the time of this review, I have logged 400 hours into this game across platforms. I have completed the community center in it's entirety, and I have perfectly optimized my farm for brutal efficiency. I make millions of dollars every season, and, for good reason, l continue pushing just to see how grotesque my industrial landscape can become. I have never spoken to a single member of the town who cannot benefit me monetarily in my personal quest for power. 

This game may be relaxed for some, but for me, it is war. There will be no item left unpurchased, no crop left ungrown, and no slime left unslain. I have become Death, destroyer of worlds. If you share a desire for ruthless expansion and power, this game is for you. If you just want to have a cute little farm and role-play a simple but idyllic rural fantasy, this game is also for you. If you value your mental health, or maintaining productivity, this game may not be for you.

There's so many things to do; Farming crops is a great way to make money and all, but for being classified as what I would call a "farming game", there's so, so much more to do than simply farm crops and take care of your animals. Relationships with characters [b][i]**really**[/i][/b] feel like they matter, but even still, the game doesn't particularly FORCE you to engage with barely anyone.


[h3]Do you like dating simulators?[/h3] This game has a mechanic where you can marry certain characters, all with their own little playable stories and cutscenes that make them feel so much more real and alive. 

[h3]More of a fighter?[/h3] The caves (and later on, the Skull Cavern) are packed with enemies to fight and treasures to find. 

[h1]Do you enjoy giving as much money to a soulless, greedy corporation that you want to distance yourself as much as possible from?[/h1] [h3]Well... you're not gonna fuckin' believe this...[/h3]

[h2]There is genuinely something in this game for anyone and everyone.[/h2] Anyone who classifies this as "just another farming game" is missing out on so much in the indie video game scene. The art and sprites are gorgeous, animations are smooth and clean, but not so much so that it feels weird for a pixel game.

I have a few nitpicks, nothing deal-breaking, just little "ugh" moments I experienced here and there:

- Forced socialization:
Why do I have to max-heart everyone in town? Plus, the friendship decay (especially with animals) is too punishing in a game aspect that's already too grindy. If that hoe Marnie sold an autopetter, that would be great. And btw, why are romanceables all young adults? We need an option for Zaddy Gus and muscle mommy Robin.

- Inventory clutters too fast:
Especially with the various qualities of fish and forageables. If tools didn't take up inventory space, that would be a huge QoL improvement (in 1.7 Eric, please?).

- The dinosaurs:
Pepper Rex are the only element that broke my suspension of disbelief. They feel so out of place in this picturesque rural setting. An eyesore.

- Unconsequential story elements:
Like the mayorâ€™s affair and his golden statue. Robin's unhappy marriage. Community center re-abandoned right after restoration...

So, after reaching perfection, unlocking all 49 achievements (I totally didn't mod the 2 cheevos for Journey of the Prairie King),

my final rating for Stardew is a resounding, unapologetic 19/20. Stardew is a lifestyle!

Never before has a game so completely engrossed, stressed, and rewarded my mind quite like Stardew Valley, though it's method of doing so is likely to vary in reflection of it's player. Stardew provides a simple basis initially - farming crops, selling them for cash, and then choosing to spend it however you see fit. But then the question is, how far do you go? Which crop is most profitable per season, and how many can you reasonably maintain over their growing period? Do you perhaps find a different activity more interesting, farming not your taste? Well then, that works too - dedicate yourself to catching high-quality fish found in only select waters, or optimise exploration of the forests for mass foraging of berries and fruits. Got more of a combative nature? Take to the mines, fighting through monsters and exhaustion levels to plumb the depths for valuable treasures. Bit of a homebody, looking to relax? Build relationships with the people around you - learn their interests, their dynamic schedules, complete requests and favours. Expand your house, indulge in interior design, live in luxury. Purchase animals, process their goods over the long-term, and then sell them for ludicrous prices. Maybe get married, have a kid or two - or don't, and instead pledge your love to the profit margins instead. Honestly, this game has something for literally everyone - and so, I must highly recommend it.

There is a glitch in the game that has never been fixed, so be aware: during the Easter Egg Hunt event, if you're playing multiplayer/co-op, only one of you may participate. If anyone else does too, the game freezes after the timer ends and everyone must restart the day, losing all progress they may have made. Also, pleeeaasseee implement a quest marker! I'm constantly failing quests and wasting days because I can't find people, and as a new player I couldn't find my way around the town very well.  But those are really the only complaints I have. It may seem like a lot but the massive content provided by the game far outweighs the cons, so I would recommend giving it a shot. (I got my husband into it and he usually hates games like this.)
